headline.main-hed: Marion Barry, Former Washington Mayor, Dies at 78

alt-summary-body.p: Former Washington, D.C, Mayor Marion Barry, whose four terms were overshadowed by his 1990 arrest after being caught on videotape smoking crack cocaine, died Sunday morning. He was 78.

headline.main-hed: Former Washington mayor Marion Barry dies at 78
Former Washington Mayor Marion Barry Dies: Update

summary-body.p: Former District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry, whose four terms were overshadowed by his 1990 arrest after being caught on videotape smoking crack cocaine, died aged 78.

headline.main-hed: Marion Barry, Former Washington Mayor, Dies at 78
headline.deck: Four Terms Overshadowed by 1990 Arrest After Being Caught on Videotape Smoking Crack

article-body.byline: By Rebecca Ballhaus and Stephen Miller
article-body.p: WASHINGTON—The first glimpse many Americans got of Marion Barry, the longtime Washington, D.C., politician, was of Federal Bureau of Investigation surveillance footage showing the then-mayor smoking crack in a hotel room with a woman not his wife.

Mr. Barry, who died early Sunday at the age of 78, was then in his third term as mayor of the nation’s capital. He retained his popularity for decades after the 1990 crack incident. After serving time in federal prison on a drug charge, he returned to be elected mayor in 1994 for a fourth term.

Mr. Barry, dubbed “Mayor for Life” by Washington City Paper columnist Ken Cummins, died early Sunday at United Medical Center in Washington, a day after being released from Howard University Hospital, according to a statement from his family. It didn’t give a cause of death, but Mr. Barry had suffered from several health problems over the years, including diabetes. He underwent a kidney transplant in 2009.

Born in Mississippi and raised by his mother in Memphis, Tenn., Marion Shepilov Barry Jr. became the first chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, which played a prominent advocacy role during the civil-rights turmoil of the 1960s.

A veteran of Southern lunch-counter sit-ins, Mr. Barry abandoned his doctoral studies in chemistry at the University of Tennessee to lead SNCC’s push for home rule in Washington, whose leaders had been appointed by the federal government for a century. Mr. Barry, a Democrat, chose his middle name in college, inspired by Dmitri Shepilov, a Russian propagandist who Mr. Barry noted in his autobiography was also “a scientist with a great memory.”

Mr. Barry led a bus boycott in the city over a fare increase and created a jobs program for poor African-Americans that attracted millions of dollars in federal grants. In 1971, he was elected to serve on the D.C. Board of Education.

Elected in 1978 as Washington’s second mayor, after home rule was established in 1975, Mr. Barry promised to champion the city’s poor, whom he referred to frequently as “the lost, the last and the least.”

In his first term, he pushed for downtown development and a cleanup of city finances. During his second term, figures close to him, including his ex-wife, Mary Treadwell, and people he had appointed to public office, were convicted of defrauding the government. During his tenure, Washington’s murder rate became the highest in the nation.

In 1990, the FBI videotaped Mr. Barry smoking crack in a Vista International Hotel room and arrested him. He was convicted of misdemeanor cocaine possession and sentenced to six months in prison. That year, he was on the ballot for a City Council seat while serving time in prison. It was the only election he lost.

Mr. Barry’s comeback was swift: Two years later, he was elected to a City Council seat representing one of the poorest parts of Washington. His campaign slogan: “He may not be perfect, but he’s perfect for D.C.”

In 1994, Mr. Barry entered the mayoral race and easily defeated the incumbent. But his fourth term was marked by severe financial complications as Washington verged on bankruptcy, prompting Congress in 1995 to take control of city finances. In 1997, Congress seized control from Mr. Barry of several of the city’s agencies, and he didn’t seek re-election the following year.

Still, he remained a fixture in D.C. politics and maintained a strong following, despite continued run-ins with the law. He was re-elected to the City Council in 2004 and continued to serve, most recently winning re-election in 2012. During that time, he was twice censured by the council for alleged ethics violations and in 2010 was stripped of his committee assignments. He also was charged in 2006 for failing to file tax returns, and he pleaded guilty.

President Barack Obama praised Mr. Barry on Sunday: “During his decades in elected office in D.C., he put in place historic programs to lift working people out of poverty, expand opportunity and begin to make real the promise of home rule,’’ Mr. Obama said in a statement. “Through a storied, at times tumultuous life and career, he earned the love and respect of countless Washingtonians.’’
Mr. Barry leaves behind his wife, Cora Masters Barry, and his son, Marion Christopher Barry.
Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
